reviewText: The Lincoln Lawyer, 2011 filmA man gets out of a car and enters a secured place. Another man talks to him about a criminal case. He talks to a bailiff about a defendant; the trial is held over. Lawyer Michael Haller stops his car to talk about that case. Haller visits his next client; "it was a set-up". The man is accused of beating a woman, but gets out on bail. Haller knows how to handle the press! He names his price to the family lawyer. A young woman is fingerprinted and processed. Haller arrives to advise her and learns what happened. Her customer paid in drugs not money, then she was caught. Haller talks to the prosecutor and makes a deal: his client will walk if she gives up this wanted man. Louis Roulé is out, Haller meets his mother. Roulé insists he is innocent, and tells his story. Note the differences in the point of view! Investigator Frank will check out the client's story. \Haller gets a ride home. Next morning Frank brings in a DVD about the event. Haller shows the DVD to the prosecutor. There is a discrepancy in the discovery file. [Prosecutors have to turn over their known facts to the defense counsel.] Haller tells his client to follow orders. A detective talks to Haller about the justice system. Later Haller meets a woman and they become very friendly. Haller studies the pictures of that woman. [Note the lack of bruises on her left side.] A prisoner insists he is innocent and won't take a deal. Haller visits a prisoner and hears his story. He reconsiders this case. Was a client really innocent? Haller has a dilemma. Can Frank find other cases like this one? Roulé makes a surprise visit to tell Mich something. The next day Haller learns his investigator was shot and killed at home! [Note the black blood from a body over an hour old.] Mick is upset and sees a man who could be involved.Later Mick talks to Maggie about "pure evil". Mick listens to his answering machine. Frank was killed by a Colt Woodsman (a .22 automatic). Did Mick have an unsecured pistol at home? The trial of Louis Roulé goes on. The police search Mick's home. They have old evidence on that Woodsman, it was a gift from Mickey Cohen. Regina Campo testifies and is cross-examined. The next day Louis Roulé testifies. "I am innocent!" There is a rebuttal witness, a man held in jail (a "snitch"). Why do people talk to him in jail? Can an old newspaper report affect the trial? There is a surprise ending! "Whose side are you on?" But there's more to come. Where is he going? There is a final confrontation. Mick knows people who can help him. There is another surprise at the end! Call 911. [It takes a good guy with a gun to stop a bad guy with a gun.] "Martinez is free." There is a repeat customer.This story starts out as an example of the practice of criminal law, then develops into a very interesting story about a murder. There was a novel in the 1960s "The Seventh Juror" about a murder trial where the real murderer was an observer in the courtroom. Would he be found out in the end?

reviewText: Yes, I know, everybody, everybody including Richard III, I think, who uttered some variation of that idea in William Shakespeare's play of the same name, hates lawyers. Hates them until old justice time comes along and everyone, including this writer, hopes to high heaven that their lawyer is up to the task of representing them zealously, and in some desperate cases more than zealously. And that combination of sentiments, that hate/love thing, is what drives this film which according to my usually reliable sources follows the Michael Connelly novel pretty closely.Needless to say, except for the thugs, pimps, dope dealers, hellish motorcycle angels, bail bondmen, public servant grifters and grafters and a bewitching lawyer ex-wife (played by Marissa Tormei) nobody, no viewer anyway, is suppose to like the Lincoln lawyer at the outset. (Named the Lincoln lawyer, by the way, not for his ethical resemblance to Father Abraham but because he rides around in a chauffeur-driven Lincoln.) His wheeling and dealing just this side of the law is what makes him the darling of that rogue's gallery of characters listed above (except, of course, the fetching ex-wife, and maybe her a little too) and the bane of the District Attorney's Office and the Los Angeles Police Department establishment.That deft and ruthless maneuvering is what also draws him to the attention of a vicious killer of women, women of the night to use a quaint phrase, and a surefire way to commit the "perfect murder" and like so many before him said murderer thought he was scot-free as is the usual case once the Lincoln lawyer was on the case. But see, said Lincoln lawyer "got religion" along the way after he and those around him were slated to take the fall if that vicious killer (a mommy's boy to boot) got tripped up.So you know damn well pretty early on that our trusty Lincoln lawyer is not taking the fall and, moreover, is going to see that an actual piece of real justice occurs in the process by the freeing a framed man who was sitting in stir through his negligence (and disbelief in innocence) by seeing that that vicious killer gets his jolt up at Q. Therefore you see we had it all wrong. There is some rough justice in the world. And one had better not kill off all those lawyers if there is going to be even that amount. The twists and turns getting there, although fairly well-worn by now in movie-dom, are what make this film one to see.

reviewText: The strengths of the film are in the writing and the acting. Both are pitch perfect. Matthew McConaughey plays a defense lawyer who cheerfully takes on guilty clients. In fact he relishes the guilty clients as he knows how to manipulate the system on their behalf and dreads ever having an innocent client as the weight of that responsibility would be unbearable.One day he is presented with a client accused of rape. The client is a typical spoiled rich kid, but McConaughey begins to suspect he is innocent and has his trusted investigator try and sort out exactly what happened. The journey to the truth is interesting and never over-wrought. Even the violence, when it comes feels organic and truthful. It is violence an actual person would commit in similar circumstances rather than heroic movie violence. The characters experience personal growth but no grand epiphanies with soaring music. Yet the movie is engaging throughout. Truly a balance between drama and realism.The acting is superb, even the smaller roles are well done and believable. To say more would spoil the plot, but Mcconaughey does have an innocent client; it just isn't the client he thinks it is. A gem and a surprise.
summary: Strikes the Balance between Drama and Realism

reviewText: Walking into `The Lincoln Lawyer', I was well aware that the film itself would have to work extra hard to earn my respect.  I don't really care much for courtroom dramas, and I find Matthew McConaughey to be a really dull presence on screen.  I know that everyone swoons over him and talks about his `Southern Charm', but I just don't buy it.  On top of that, I just don't find him to be a convincing actor.  I don't see layers in his work; I merely see a lazy approach to telling the same character over and over.  There has been a lot of talk of the sudden upswing in his career, starting with this particular film and moving right on into his string of successful turns this year.  Much has been made of his Oscar chances for `Magic Mike' and he's getting career best notices for the savage drama `Killer Joe'.  Needless to say, I didn't care much.  I have yet to see any of his films from this year and I wasn't really anticipating them much to tell you the truth.  When I hear the name Matthew McConaughey I don't expect much.So, last night I settled in to catch up on my DVR recordings and I noticed that I had `The Lincoln Lawyer' on my DVR.  I didn't record it, must have been the wife, but I wasn't really in the mood to think and so I decided to give it a whirl, since I expected it to be `good' at best and hardly something I'd feel compelled to dissect.I have to learn to stop judging every book by its cover.As a film, `The Lincoln Lawyer' is riveting and kept me glued throughout.  I was stunned.  The plot twists are engaging, and while the obviousness of the `villain' is a little too on the nose from the start, it becomes an easily forgivable offence since they aren't really interested in keeping his innocence ambiguous for very long.  The progression of the plot is well done and expertly paced by director Brad Furman, who holds onto the tension efficiently.  The final courtroom scene is pulse-racing for sure, and basically exemplifies everything that a courtroom drama should be.  In fact, I loved the fact that I never knew what Mick's next move would be and why he was making it, but when it all fell into place it made perfect sense.And that brings me to Mick, or should I say, Matthew McConaughey.  Why do I call this a case of Oscar snubbery?  I don't know if I'd personally nominate him, considering that last year was ridiculously strong, but a very solid case can be made for McConaughey being a snub because this role is every bit a perfect one to garner a star their first Oscar nomination.  What McConaughey does here is actually quite remarkable, and I don't say there merely because he took me by surprise or because I expected him to fail.  Any other actor in the role doing what he does would have garnered the same response from me.  I am not one to shy away from eating crow, and that is what I must do here.Something that I have always accused Matthew of doing is giving us a surface performance, with no actual depth.  I understand that in the beginning of his career he tried the whole `soul searching drama' stuff, and he did do `A Time to Kill' and yet I didn't care much for what he did in that film and so it doesn't count for me.  I've never felt that he has ever gotten under the skin of the character much at all; until now.  As Mick Haller, McConaughey layers so much on this man it's ridiculous.  In fact, the more I think about it the more stunned I am by the scope of his performance.  Mick is suave and under control and possesses that `Southern Charm' and sheer confidence that makes him a firm presence in any room.  That is something that McConaughey should be able to handle in his sleep.  But it is the tiny layers of panic that ride through his face when no one is looking that took me by surprise.  Mick wasn't just a stone, and as this `case' took over his personal life and threatened him in the severest of ways, you saw those cracks.  McConaughey let us in to see the inner turmoil, but then batted an eyelash and firmed up his stance and delivered a `performance' for the rest of the room that read otherwise.  Mick is a showman, and McConaughey mastered that aspect of his persona with ease.  The way he plays his part in the courtroom or the way he betrays his own panic by laying a threat of confidence out on his `client' is compelling and 100% believable.  The anger that floods his motives is also stirring and he sells his biggest moments with such authenticity.  I appreciated that he never overacted here, and there was place for it.  Instead, he displayed an honest depiction of emotional outbursts that stayed true to the man he was portraying.When all is said and done, Mick Haller may be human, but he is one cool cat.So, I give this very high marks.  The film is intriguing and engrossing from start to finish.  It has the ability to veer into `television courtroom drama' territory, as do a lot of films in this genre, and yet it pulls back with a glossy treatment and a plot that thickens rather well.  It's more `CSI: Miami' than `Law & Order', but Matthew McConaughey delivers a star performance that puts David Caruso to shame.

reviewText: First of all, I'll be upfront about this movie. I never got the title until I saw the extras. The extras explain that Matthew McConaghey's lawyer character works out of his Lincoln Continental car. Maybe I'm slow on the uptake but if the whole setup was this lawyer found it more convenient to work from his car, then I missed that. Even though there are lots of scenes of him going to and from court to wherever driven by his chauffeur, I just thought the open briefcase, the talking on the cell phone and the meeting up with the Hell's Angels clients on the road were all they were.In another scene you see McConaghey going through old files in his garage so I just assumed he worked out of his home. Anyway, that's where I'm coming from.The extras also pointed out by the book's author upon which the movie is based that the action occurs in this one justice area in Van Nuys, California, that houses various buildings such as a holding jail, courthouse and various bail bonds offices. In the movie I never figured that out as when they cut from scenes in each of these places you never really see McConaghey walk from one building to the next.So in this sense despite a terrific movie that has great characters, tremendous twists and turns, great supporting cast (Marisa Tomei and John Leguizamo are among the "names") a very evil Ryan Philippe, I don't think the director who converted the book to screen if it took the extras (which are all pretty terrific) really was able to give us a sense that much of the courtroom and prisoner-lawyer scenes were all within virtually the same block.The extras (and sorry to go on about them more than the actual movie but they really are terrific) also had the author Michael Connelly (a former LA Times crime reporter)take us on a drive around the LA of the Lincoln lawyer which was endlessly fascinating and very much Raymond Chandler-esque.

reviewText: THE LINCOLN LAWYERSTARRING: Matthew McConaughey, Ryan Philippe, Marisa Tomei, William H. Macy, Michael Pena, John Leguizamo and Josh LucasWRITTEN BY: John Romano; based on the novel by Michael ConnellyDIRECTED BY: Brad FurmanRated: RGenre: Drama / ThrillerRelease Date: 18 March 2011Review Date: 18 March 2011The Lincoln Lawyer was a refreshing film for two paramount reasons: it's one of the top films of the year and its Matthew McConaughey's best performance to date. I generally like McConaughey movies but he's played a lot of goofballs.More often than not he's a buffoon or a slacker who has beautiful women flocking to him and we never question it because he's Matthew McConaughey. The ladies in his films never question it for this same reason and because he usually has his shirt off. But here he's charming, intelligent, slick, and meticulously perfect at everything; particularly the work he does from the back seat of his Lincoln. We'd believe any woman's attraction to him. Ironically, only one woman shows interest in him and it's an old flame.She's Maggie, played by the lovely Marisa Tomei. The two are lawyers who remain friends who may want a little more. The iceberg between them is that they are on either sides of the fence when it comes to the law. She wants bad guys behind bars; he couldn't care less if they're on the street so long as they can afford his hefty fees.McConaughey slides into the role of Mick Haller with great ease and does a tremendous job. Mick lives to be in a courtroom and finds great euphoria in winning and knowing that he will win without question. We love watching him in action. As good as this film was, I imagine the detail that went into the novel, of which it's based, was even more enticing. Even John Grisham is likely a fan.We spend the first several minutes of the film being acquainted with the big sleaze ball Mick is. He handles multiple cases at a time: hookers, drug dealers, whatever; and seems to have them settled in his head before he even steps foot in court.All that changes however with his latest client: a rich kid accused of a brutal rape (Ryan Philippe). All fingers point to his being guilty, but he insists otherwise. Ryan Philippe isn't as good here as he was as a similar rich snob in Cruel Intentions, but he's pretty close.To reveal what happens next would be inconceivable to anyone who's seen the film. It spirals out of control over and over and it's the kind of film that makes you think while entertaining the hell out of you. It's one of those rare movies that actually could happen yet still has us captivated. Oh, and McConaughey only removes his shirt once.

reviewText: Mick Haller is a street-smart lawyer with an ex-wife, a young daughter, and an ego.  His bondsman has just snagged him another case: Louis Roulet, accused of sexual assault and attempted murder.  Roulet professes innocence, and Haller, for once, believes him.  But the case is deeper and murkier than it appears on the surface, and Haller is about to be confronted with something even worse than an innocent client: true evil.Brad Furman's THE LINCOLN LAWYER hews fairly close to the Michael Connolly source novel for the first two-thirds, which presents some good things (suspense, an interesting lead character) and bad things (major plot holes and contrivances).  Matthew McConaughey is perfect for the role of Haller (apparently, Connolly himself wanted McConaughey for the role); he never truly sinks his teeth in, but he's sufficiently charming, troubled, and devious to keep you entertained.  The film features a great deal of talented actors (Bryan Cranston, John Leguizamo, Marisa Tomei, William H. Macy, Shea Whigham, and Michael Pena) who never truly get their chance to shine, and other mediocre actors (Josh Lucas, Ryan Phillippe, even Trace Adkins for God's sake) who get stuck with two-dimensional characters.In it's final act, though, THE LINCOLN LAWYER diverges from the novel, and this presents a major problem: the moral ambiguity Connolly built up so effectively is utterly lost.  This doesn't completely ruin the movie--note the three stars--but it puts a damper on things.  Still, fans of the genre won't care.  If you want a slick thriller, with a touch of suspense, a charming lead, and a bit of intrigue, THE LINCOLN LAWYER is right up your (well-lit) alley.
summary: A slick, breezy, entertaining legal thriller.

reviewText: The MovieWhat we have here is a nice thriller about a lawyer named Mickey Haller (Matthew McConaughey) taking a case that he will soon find out details and clues as to what he really has got himself involved in. Without giving anything away, the case he gets involved in is about a 32 year old male named Louis Roulet (played by Ryan Philippe) accused of beating up a prostitute. What Haller finds out throughout the case is clues about other cases he has took and all of this leads to frustration considering he finds out he is sort of stuck between a rock and a hard place (you will see why when you watch). The story does take time to evolve. Actually, things go quite slowly for the first 40 minutes or so and then things get going after that. There is a slow build up of suspense throughout, but for what its worth, the 2 hour run time does seem a bit longer considering how dragged out parts of the movie were. On the other hand, we have a good supporting cast around McConaughey including Ryan Philippe, Marisa Tomei, William H. Macy, and even our buddy Bryan Cranston from Breaking Bad makes a couple of brief appearances. I thought all the characters did a very good job in this film, however, The Lincoln Lawyer was all too predictable for the most part which made it less enjoyable than I thought it was going to be. Perhaps the end of the movie picked up too quickly and a lot of things happened at once, but overall this movie deserves a 4 rating which in my book is pretty good, but not great.Video QualityDepth is very strong and black levels are deep. This is a very detailed and impressive presentation for the most part. The views outside had quite a bit of depth to them. Palm trees, pavement, scenery, you name it, had high amounts of detail. The presentation was also nice and filmic. There were some scenes with some very light banding if I had one nitpick. Otherwise the video quality is pretty awesome.Audio QualityThis is not going to be your big budget action movie with explosions, but the DTS-HD MA track got the job done. It does contain a 7.1 mix so those of you with a 7.1 setup will surely be pleased. If you are renting the disc it looks like there is only a 5.1 mix which is really stupid if you ask. Lionsgate must have pressed different copies for the rental edition. Anyways, this is primarily a dialogue driven film and it is delivered very well. The surround speakers were used quite well too at times. You could pick up a lot of little things that were going on in and around the court room from time to time. Better yet was the hip hop tunes that would play and the scenes with the motorcycles. The sound stage came alive during these scenes.

reviewText: A compelling film if you don't mind the usual courtroom thriller tropes--e.g., Why oh why does the defense attorney always have to be exes with the hotty prosecutor? {At least here, she's not the opposing counsel he's facing in the Big Upcoming Trial.} Despite some very unlikely situations, THE LINCOLN LAWYER's twists and turnabouts are better than average, and once this film really gets going, it keeps the attention without much difficulty.There will be mixed reactions to McGonaughey's performance as Mr. Slick-and-Slimey, Ultra-Mercenary, Hard-Drinking, Wisecracking, Craftily Hackish Defense Counsel Mick Haller. He's about as stock a character as there can be, but then again, he acts just like many real-life trial lawyers actually DO act. I think this film reveals quite well the role that he's ingrained in himself--the lawyer as actor, etc, etc. Many of the supporting characters, particularly the cops, bikers, and bad guys, are effectively portrayed. William Macy (as Haller's P.I.) and Shea Whigham (as Corliss the jailhouse snitch) are especially in-character and add a nice dose of reality here.In search of more specific things to say about THE LINCOLN LAWYER, I notice that the majority of the other reviewers here basically like it but don't have that many specific observations to make either. It's just a good thriller: That's all.

reviewText: Judge David Johnson, DVD Verdict -- "You know what The Lincoln Lawyer feels like? Old school. I have a difficult time putting my finger on why I feel that way, but it just seems we don't get a lot of movies like these out of the studios these days. There are no visual effects, no bombast, no 3D gimmicks. It's just an actor and a story cleverly told. Credit to McConaughey for bringing this guy to life. He really is electric here, further bolstering his impressive portfolio of attorney roles; he's got that way of being slick and in command and approachable without coming across as a douchebag--vital ingredients to pulling the Haller character off. And though we may be deprived of a neck-twisting Primal Fear-like twist, the thrills are still potent and the payoff is rewarding. Extras are headlined by three HD featurettes: an overall making-of documentary, a tour of LA with Michael Connelly, an interview with McConaughey conducted by Connelly, and a handful of deleted scenes. The 2.35:1, 1080p transfer is a great piece of visual fidelity, and we get a 7.1 DTS-HD audio mix! I thought those were extinct."
summary: A taut, well-acted thriller and a solid Blu-ray

reviewText: I'm not a huge Matthew McConaughey fan, but I did like him in "A Time to Kill." While I haven't read the original novel, my wife and I figured "The Lincoln Lawyer" might be a good midweek flick, and we were right.McConaughey is Mickey Haller, a defense attorney who seems to do most of his business from the back of an old Lincoln. He's shrewd, wily, and fits right in with those he represents from the shadier side of the streets. As far as he's concerned, he doesn't ever have to feel bad if he loses a case because he knows all his clients are essentially guilty. It seems, though, that his father once warned him about the day he would represent an innocent client. Sure enough, his father's warning proves prescient when Haller ends up being retained by an ultra-wealthy L.A. client, a young man played by Ryan Philippe. This man has been accused of assaulting a hooker in the midst of a transaction, and indeed he was discovered with her blood on his hands, but he swears his innocence.Haller takes the case. He makes a lot of money from it. But he also uncovers some small lies by his client. What is his client trying to protect? Does it have something to do with a rich mother who suffered abuse of her own? Soon Haller is getting pulled back into an old case and is questioning his own judgment, even while trying to make amends with his ex-wife and his young daughter.It's pretty obvious early on that something is not right, but the manner in which this unfolds, both in the courtroom and on the streets, makes this a fast-paced and entertaining story. It has some lessons hidden in there about justice and the flaws in the legal system, particularly apropos after the Casey Anthony trial, but it never rises to greatness. There are some sloppy moments that may have worked better in book form. For example, I kept wondering how a Maserati managed to go unnoticed in slum areas, especially when the driver was supposed to be oh, so intelligent.In the long run, Haller lives up to his own tarnished and questionable character by meting out justice on his own terms. He doesn't prove himself above the law, but he does show that he has a penchant for wanting the truth and wanting justice at all costs, if it means protecting the truly innocent. It leads to some interesting ethical discussions without ever taking itself too seriously in the process.

reviewText: Michael Connelly's 2005 novel, The Lincoln Lawyer, garnered critical and commercial success. The film adaptation stays loyal to the novel, and is very entertaining.Matthew McConaughey portrays the main character Mickey Haller as a kind of lovable, bad boy. Haller is a lawyer who has made a career of representing criminals and outcasts. He runs his practice out of his old Lincoln, and drives around town looking for his next case. Early on in the film, we are introduced to his ex-wife, played by Marisa Tomei, with whom he has a young daughters. It is in these moments that we get to see the softer side of Haller.The story really gets moving when Haller is called to represent Roulet, a high profile, Los Angeles playboy who is accused of murdering a prostitute. Despite a bad gut feeling, Haller knows that this case could be the high point of his career. With the help of his own investigator Frank Levin, played by a show-stealing William H. Macey, Haller soon finds a connection to a previous case that has haunted him for years.Overall, the film is a great mix of action, intrigue and comedy. McConaughey's everyman persona really helps Haller to be relatable and an effective protagonist. Ryan Phillippe is surprisingly effective at staying in the grey area as Roulet. The real star of the movie is Macey, who's appearance is cut short way too soon. This movie effectively captures the essence of Connelly's novel while still adjusting to the new medium. While this adaptation is pretty black and white, it is still very entertaining.

reviewText: The strength of this movie is its excellent pacing- it barrels along at a brisk, engaging pace, keeping the viewer interested in what might come next. The legal jargon strikes that sweet spot of being interesting and somewhat complex, without ever going into the mind-numbing realm of the incomprehensible.Of equal significance is the outstanding performance of Matthew McConaughey. He pours on his charisma at full blast, and even though he's a defense lawyer who makes a living of representing the worst scum in the state of Texas, you can't help but like the guy (even before he begins to question the morals of his life choices).As for the plot itself, it's decent- not ground breaking by any means, but this is a solid legal thriller. The mystery aspects are presented in a fairly interesting manner, though the characters' motives can be a bit implausible/nonsensical at times. The "Lincoln Lawyer" is "comfort food" for people who want to watch a movie that plays out like a John Grisham novel.

reviewText: THE LINCOLN LAWYER is a classy, well-written (adapted from Michael Connelly's novel by John Romano), well-directed (Brad Furman) drama that benefits from the presence of a well chosen, first class cast. This is one of the stronger movies of the year, the kind of film that reminds us of the art of cinema.Mike Haller (Matthew McConaughey in a brilliant performance) is a money hungry smarmy defense lawyer whose brilliant mind is bent toward representing sleazy types who pay well.  He works out of his Lincoln automobile driven by his trusted ally Earl (Laurence Mason), lives in a dumpy apartment, works with a shoddy appearing detective Frank (William H Macy), and spars with the beautiful fellow lawyer Maggie McPherson (Marisa Tomei) with whom he has a daughter and an on again off again relationship. One of his fellow workers Val Valenzuela (John Leguizamo) tips Mike on a case of  wealthy realtor Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe) who is accused of beating a prostitute: the case smells of lots of money so Mike of course takes it on - along with Louis, wealthy mother Mary Windsor (Frances Fisher) and the family lawyer Cecil Dobbs (Bob Gunton).  Mike's investigation turns up evidence that suggests his client is not the 'presumed innocent' he appears and there are connections between this case and an old case Mike handled - Jesus Martinez (Michael Peña) - and Mike's usual 'go for the money' attitude takes a turn toward actually seeking justice in the courtroom. A shady dealing lawyer does actually have a conscience and finds a way to prove the truth will out.There are many cameo roles worthy of mentioning - Josh Lucas plays the prosecuting attorney Ted Minton, Pell James is Mike's girl Friday Lorna, Margarita Levieva is the victim prostitute Reggie Campo, Trace Adkins plays the motorcycle gang head Eddie Vogel, and Shea Whigham inhabits the role of the jail snitch DJ Corliss.  But the major attraction here is Matthew McConaughey's Oscar worthy role: he is magnetic in his transformation from a lawyer you want to loathe to a victor you want to hail.  Marisa Tomei is once again given the opportunity to demonstrate just how fine an actress she is. This is a fast moving, well-scripted film that is simply one of the better moves to come out in a while.  Highly recommended.  Grady Harp, July 11

reviewText: Sometimes, a pretty boy actor doesn't get interesting until he's developed a few more wrinkles on his face, gravitas on his mug, suggesting a life having lived. Of late, Matthew McConaughey has been dismissed by naysayers as a good-looking huckster, grinning that toothy grin, flexing those ripped abs. And he hasn't done himself any favors with his recent cinematic outings (GHOSTS OF GIRLFRIENDS PAST, really?). THE LINCOLN LAWYER, adapted from Michael Connelly's novel, should get his critics off his back some. It's a corker of a legal thriller, and McConaughey hasn't been this watchable in years.McConaughey plays Mick Haller, Los Angeles's slickest criminal defense attorney, the sort of sleazy legal practitioner that Atticus Finch longs to take behind the woodshed. Mick, who works out of the back seat of his classic Lincoln Town Car, has sold out a long time ago. He doesn't give an ef if a guy is guilty or not as long as the money's good. He lists on his rolodex some of L.A.'s shadiest lowlifes. Although, this time out, he's landed a posh client (Ryan Phillippe) accused of assault and attempted murder, except that this uppercrust young gent claims his innocence. But they all say they're innocent, ain't that so? Mick Haller regards this as a slam-dunk case. The rest of us know better. Strap in for a rollercoaster ride of ruses, runarounds, and reversals.It's a solid supporting cast. I am so glad Marisa Tomei got cast instead of some vapid model-type. Tomei is a real-looking woman and beautiful. She plays Mick Haller's fierce rival in court, a tough prosecutor as well as his ex-wife and the mother of his daughter. When the chips are down, she becomes Mick's most steadfast anchor. William H. Macy again makes lemonade out of lemon with his otherwise-would've-been-blah part of Mick's investigator. John Leguizamo does his usual squirrelly thing as a bail bondsman who tips off Mick to this plum case (but even that's a lie). In just a few short scenes Michael Peña provides one of the film's most sobering moments as he transitions from Mick's weepy panic-struck client to a hardened, dead-eyed convict. Josh Lucas, whom I always regarded as something of a McConaughey look-alike, goes up against McConaughey in court and he's pretty workmanlike, but not bad.There's enough twisty material here to make you lean into the screen. As Mick unearths deception after deception, he begins to suspect that his rich client may well be guilty (but is he?). One knock against the plot is that it does seem a bit too contrived that one of Mick's old cases happens to tie into this new one. There's a nasty, low-down feel to this story, a scruffy edginess, and it grips you. McConaughey invests a measure of grit and slime into his performance, and I really enjoyed it. Check out his Mick Haller, sly as a serpent, fast-talking, deal-making, working all the angles, scruples gathering dust on the shelf. Except that there may be a twinge of righteousness still left in Mick Haller which might make him turn a corner. Or is that another red herring? THE LINCOLN LAWYER doesn't achieve the heights of THE VERDICT or A FEW GOOD MEN, but it does what it sets out to do. It is a ripping legal thriller and comes at you with attitude. It is hopefully the first in a film franchise. After all, Michael Connelly's written four novels starring our morally grey counselor. And McConaughey's got them wrinkles now. Take advantage of that, yo.

Yet, as stated, this is a very good film because the acting is consistently very good, and Matthew McConaughey gives an even better performance than he usually gives. reviewText: Remember the last good movie Matthew McConaughey was in?  You have to reach back a way, but it was Time to Kill, where he played a lawyer whose life gets turned upside down after taking a high profile case in which there are questions of the defendant's actual guilt.  It should come as no surprise then, that his role as Mick Haller - a slick-talking, deal-cutting, lowlife-defending criminal defense lawyer whose life gets turned upside down after taking a nearly identical case (at least outwardly) - produces a crisp, if somewhat unoriginal, movie high on intense legal thrills and unsolved mysteries.  The primary dissimilarity is rather than superb oratory skills used on a sympathetic jury, Haller uses the flaws and loopholes in the legal system to his advantage in an effort to correct wrongs as he sees them.  This does not gain him favor with the prosecuting attorneys who view Haller as bottom-feeding scum.  Secondary to lawyer differences is the client.  Instead of a poor black man it's a rich white man (Ryan Phillipe as Louis Roulet, perfect casting for the entitled WASP).  The two movies are so similar McConaughey even has a hot wife in this one (Marisa Tomei); although, she's not as hot as her film predecessor (Ashley Judd).  Speaking of Judd, this movie is believable, unlike the legal dramas she's been in.  Which is probably why it's so engrossing.When a man (Roulet) accused of beating a hooker (Hooker), a sleazy bail-bondsman (Leguizamo) gets Haller and his P.I. (Macy) the case.  Once the details begin to get exposed, mystery and truth is revealed.  As the shady deals, criminal informants, and plot twists unravel, The Lincoln Lawyer displays how a superb mystery can be crafted without a ton of extraneous fluff thrown in for no other reason than masturbatory screen-writing.An all around fine film that has very little room for improvement.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: There is something so satisfying about seeing two really smart people in a battle of wits. It's one of my favorite plot devices. For me, another favorite is handsome men...and look at this cast:* Matthew McConaughey ("We Are Marshall") is a slick, successful, street-wise lawyer, but he actually believes in Justice. His office is a Lincoln town car.* Ryan Phillippe ("Breach") is his client, accused of rape and attempted murder. This baby-faced character presents quite a quandary: Is he or is he not guilty?* Josh Lucas ("Glory Road" - I've been a fan since "Sweet Home Alabama") is the prosecutor confronted by death of a thousand cuts. It's not as bad as it sounds.* Michael Paré ("Hope Floats" and for you hard-core fans, "Eddie and the Cruisers") is a frustrated detective.* John Leguizamo ("Moulin Rouge!") is the fast-talking street guy who pulls our hero into the game.* William H. Macy ("Shameless") is our hero's right-hand man, quick, resourceful...and funny.* Laurence Mason (LOTS of TV) is his chauffeur; he has the best line: "You're nobody 'til somebody shoots you!"The female roles are mostly window dressing except for Frances Fisher ("Jolene") who plays the accused fellow's mother; the script has plenty of laughs, with many upbeat characters and a twisty plot worth following. By the time we know what happened, we still can't see where we're going.All in all, this is an exciting, satisfying, well-shot film with plenty of people to root for, very little profanity, no car chases and no blowie uppie stuff.
summary: Two Smart People in a Battle of Wits

reviewText: This film is about a criminal defense lawyer who practices out of his Lincoln Towncar.  The movie embraces many of the lawyer stereotypes and shows Attorney Mickey Haller (played by McConaughey) wheeling and dealing with his clients to make a buck.  For instance, in several scenes, Haller is shown strong-arming his criminal clients into paying by delaying a trial or making up excuses about the costs of expert witnesses.  Much of what was shown would be unethical and violate the rules of professional responsibility applicable to all attorneys.  But, it makes for good drama.Without giving too much away, one underlying issue is the impact of the "attorney-client privilege" (a rule that forbids disclosure of confidential information about a client) as it relates to his representation of a present client while learning of information that could exonerate a former client.  Throughout the plot, the audience is given a few twists as Haller investigates the crime and learns what "really" happened.  In my opinion, most are predictable.  But, it is clever how they put it all together in this film.One of the most interesting parts, in my view, is how Haller gets around attorney-client privilege and cleverly obtains justice in the end.  When you watch it, notice when the detective asks "why did you subpoena me" to come to the trial.  The reason is obvious if you think back to the detective's asking about the client who was in San Quentin and the implication that the detective was familiar with that case.In the end, it is a great legal drama.

reviewText: "The Lincoln Lawyer" with more twists and turns than a corkscrew reminded me of those classic L.A. crime thrillers like "Chinatown," and the hardboiled school of Dashiell Hammett, Raymond Chandler, and James M. Cain. Mickey Haller is a shrewd lawyer who manipulates the law, but can't stand it when he gets set-up and framed. In this one there are multiple set-ups. It is very cleverly woven together. The acting is serviceable and effective, but not superb. It is filmed very neatly with a fast pace that adds to the suspense. It is partly courtroom histrionics, but much of the action takes place outside the courtroom.Mickey is played by Matthew McConaughey, and he is well-cast for the part as is Ryan Phillippe, his client who is accused of an assault upon a woman. Mickey is a scammer who even scams the stuffy family attorney with a videotaping scheme.At the beginning everything happens at a breakneck speed, and it is difficult to hear the rapid conversation. It settles down, and we catch our breath. Phillippe plays spoiled and wealthy Louis Roulet who fervently pleads his innocence. Haller has been dealing with the lower echelons of the accused, and he needs a financial break. He's represented a member of a biker gang, a mob that shows up regularly in the movie and comes in handy. Other unsavory clients and cases have been Haller's stock and trade. He gets chauffered around in a Lincoln limo by a man who owes Mickey money for handling his drug case.Get ready for layers of plot intrigue, ploys and mazes within mazes. Never try to scam a scammer, because he's probably going to catch on. I got pulled into this narrative, and the time flew by.Author Michael Connelly has consistently turned out the best American crime novels of anyone out there. His detective Harry Bosch is legendary. Mickey Haller is a good addition to the Connelly cast. I can see a sequel on the horizon because there are several Haller books in my library.
summary: Don't try to Scam a Scammer

reviewText: Matthew McConaughey is a talented actor who has spent the last ten years making forgettable romantic-comedies that stunt his ability to show his range. While The Lincoln Lawyer does not have him stepping into Oscar-worthy territory, it's a role that renews faith in his ability as an actor. Additionally, it's a solid film with a tremendous supporting cast and confident direction from relative newcomer Brad Furman (whose IMDB picture, with his Good Charlotte T-shirt and sideways hat, would not lead you to believe he was capable of making a coherent film).McConaughey plays Mick Haller, a smooth-talking Los Angeles defense attorney who operates out of the backseat of his Lincoln Town Car, defending garden-variety criminals who can pay the right price. Mick is very good at his job and clearly fond of the luxuries it affords. When his driver, Earl, asks him if he can keep the job after Mick gets his license back, Mick replies "I got my license back three months ago, Earl." Out of the blue, a bail bondsman named Val (John Leguizamo) approaches Mick with an offer to defend a high-profile client; Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe), the son of a wealthy real estate mogul, has been accused of brutally assaulting a prostitute. Louis vehemently professes his innocence and, although he is suspicious, Mick takes the job. Along with Frank Levin (William H. Macy), his investigator, Mick begins analyzing the evidence to build his case and finds discrepancies that only make his suspicions stronger...The Lincoln Lawyer starts with a strong script, no doubt adapted from a strong book. I am not familiar with the author of the novel, Michael Connelly, but the last film adapted from one of his books was the 2002 Clint Eastwood thriller Blood Work, which was well-received. Two solid films out of two ain't bad; I think it's a safe bet that he's got talent. The script follows the formula of including a twist at every opportunity and this twisty plot keeps the film surprising and interesting. There are elements that require you to suspend your disbelief a bit (nothing too extraordinary, just too convenient) and it does get contrived at times, but it's much smarter and fun than the average Hollywood legal thriller. There are really two types of films here, the first hour being a mystery while the second being a legal thriller. I was a bit taken aback when they spill the beans only an hour in, but found the courtroom drama just as engrossing as what came before it. The mystery element is effectively intriguing, while the courtroom stuff is well-played, with intensity and snappy dialogue.It's been a long time since McConaughey was in such fine form. This is a role with real bite and he reminds us that he's a movie star with genuine acting ability. Mick Haller is a suave, charismatic, arrogant, crafty, and manipulative character that McConaughey really sinks his teeth into. As an actor, he naturally exudes charisma and he takes to this character in the same natural way a Jazz musician takes to their instrument. Marissa Tomei as the L.A. prosecutor, and Mick's ex-wife, has a natural chemistry with McConaughey and a likeability and natural warmth that brightens up a film just by having her walk on-screen. Macy doesn't have much screen-time, but has the unique ability as an actor to bring a distinct quirkiness to his role and effectively steal all of his scenes. As the comic relief of sorts, he does just that here. The stunning supporting cast is not short on big names and big talent, consisting of Josh Lucas, Frances Fisher, Michael Peña, Bryan Cranston, and Trace Adkins (!?).The Lincoln Lawyer is consistently entertaining and suspenseful while it moves at a brisk, clever pace. It has structural similarities to recent films (one that comes immediately to mind is 2007's Fracture), but what it lacks in freshness it makes up for in execution. This is not a film that tries to reinvent the wheel, but merely keep its audience entertained while they watch the wheel spin. It's well-acted and addictive. It's nice to see a film that that aspires only to entertain, but doesn't disregard intelligence completely in doing so. It's not a great film, but it's great entertainment.GRADE: B

reviewText: This film is entertaining and well-acted, but in the end I give a mere 3 stars, because it is so unreal in certain important ways.The Story:Matthew McConaughey plays a street-wise, prison-wise lawyer (Mickey Haller) who works the system to make a living.  In some ways he's a sleazy guy, representing biker gangs, bribing clerks for info etc, but he's also got a kind heart for his daughter, his ex and his friend Frank (Bill Macy, a private investigator).  I think it's good role for McConaughey, and like a lot of other Hollywood "pretty boys" (e.g. Tom Cruise, Leonardo DiCaprio) his acting gets better as he ages and plays more serious parts.  If you'd ever gotten accused of a crime, his Mickey Haller character would be the guy you'd hire to battle the system!Haller comes upon a case of a snobby rich young man (Ryan Phillippe) who is accused of a nasty assault on a prostitute, and takes over the case from the family's clueless "blue-blood" lawyer.  Then the story gets intriguing, as you wonder if the rich kid is "playing" Haller.  Then you realize that he is, big time, especially when Macy gets killed, and Haller seems like he's in a deep hole that's impossible to get out of.  It's when he's in this impossible-seeming situation that McConaughey's acting skills come out.  Is he a cool lawyer with the whole world at his feet, or a lonely, angry, divorced drunk who is barely clinging on without losing it?  It's this time of desparation & suffering that gives the movie a little more depth than your typical formulaic film noir.All Haller has to do is lose the case and the rich snob will be jailed for a long, long time.  But he's set on winning the case for his client and simultaneously getting his client booked for murder. How he does this is a little too slick for me to believe, but I admit it's good escapism.  Also, as many viewers say, the movie has well acted characters.So WHAT'S WRONG with this movie (SPOILER ALERT BELOW!)?  It took me a while of contemplation to figure this out.  What's wrong with its message? Why doesn't it resonate with me?  It's because it is a total warping of reality.  This movie, while it PURPORTS to be realistic, is total BS reality-wise.  A sleazy defense lawyer who is amoral and works the system for money, is the hero?  A white, handsome, upper-class, Ferrari-driving real-estate salesman and his well-dressed successful Mother are evil Bad Guys, like the Joker and the Riddler?  Biker gangs are other heros who are on the side of the hero?  Of course, we HAVE TO BE PC.  SO ... can't have Blacks or Hispanics, who are 95% of the gang population in LA, be the criminals!  No!  The gang-looking latino who was put in jail for murder, was framed!  He even says "My Mom is going to die when she knows I'm going to jail!"  He says it so well, you think you're going to cry!  Forget about all those other gangbangers who aren't innocent (like the guys who beat the Giants fan into a coma), this movie tells you that you just can't generalize!So the movie (& I assume the book) depicts a flipped reality in which the population that is probably responsible for <1% of the violent crime in the US (rich, white, USC-educated real-estate selling golfers, AND their mothers) are the evil-doers.  And everyone else in the non-upper-class world: prostitutes, ex-hippies, minorities, bikers, sleaze-bags, are just fine ... i.e. they're GOOD PEOPLE.  Who we should really hate are those rich golfing bastards, not only because we're jealous of their money, and they're not taxed enough of course, but they are evil serial killers to boot and guarded by their homicidal 65 year-old Armani-clothed mothers.In other words, what passes for a thriller on the surface is also very manipulative class warfare and PC propaganda.  But I guess it's worth a few bucks for some temporary escapism.
summary: Slick legal escapism, well-acted characters -- so WHAT'S WRONG WITH IT? (Note Spoiler Alert)

reviewText: This legal thriller is a refreshing break from all of the mindless, style-over-substance 3D fare Hollywood is churning out lately. It's a throwback to the days of classic courtroom dramas and police procedurals, with enough interesting twists and turns to keep eyeballs glued to the screen. Matthew McConaughey is superbly cast as the smooth operator lawyer. The rest of the casting is also exceptional, down to some of the bit parts like the bail bondsman, the jailhouse snitch, the biker, and the busted hooker. (I especially appreciated William H. Macy as the private investigator; I do wish that Marisa Tomei had a meatier role that allowed her to shine as she did in "My Cousin Vinny.") Michael Connelly is one of the best current authors in the hard-boiled police procedural genre, and the adaptation stays pretty true to his spirit. As someone who works in the criminal justice system, I appreciated the realism. Money, connections, backroom wheeling and dealing, and simple twists of fate often trump justice. Just four stars because although it was solid and great fun to watch, it lacked a profound message or deep impact that would make it  memorable. You certainly won't regret watching it.CAUTION: If you have not seen this movie, do not watch the trailer. It spoils the plot.

reviewText: I found this overall to be just so-so. On the plus side, the story is interesting, a justice system whodunit with a fair number of unexpected twists. Matthew McConaughey plays a hustling defense attorney who at first seems to possess no scruples, but who soon emerges as much more complex. Ryan Phillipe is his rich playboy client, who initially proclaims his innocence, but of course doubt prevails. Marisa Tomei co-stars as McConaughey's ex-wife who is also a prosecutor, and William Macy as his investigator.The main problem with the movie for me was the writing, particularly the dialogues. Most of the conversations feel very artificial, and rushed - the story is at pains to fit in all the twists I think, and so each scene revolves around the information it is meant to convey, as opposed to being driven by character or realism. In that it felt a bit like an extended Law and Order episode, rather than a high- level feature film. The characters felt thin for the same reason, particularly the Marisa Tomei and William Macy characters - both fine actors who are completely under/mis- used here. Matthew McConaughey and Ryan Phillipe both felt a bit wooden to me, even when they were angry, also probably partly due to the writing.So story is OK, writing and acting so-so, just a 3-star film for me.
summary: Found This Just So-So -- Story Good, Writing and Performances Uneven

reviewText: I wish I could give this 3.5 stars...I feel three stars is a little bit low, as it was enjoyable and I will probably watch it again (I bought it before viewing).  However, I don't think it really warrants 4 stars.  As a fledgling attorney, I wasn't all that happy with the way the justice system is portrayed here (particularly the star attorney).  I know he is meant to be a "hero" as he is lashing out at the bad guy and helping to free the innocent man, but I had a hard time liking him because of his methods.  NOTE: I know this is probably a minority viewpoint, so if you don't think this will bother you, I would recommend it as a good watch.As as I said to my husband after the first 45 minutes or so "oh so many ethical violations"; whether he thinks he is doing the right thing or not, the main character commits numerous ethical violations at the beginning, and again at the end after he realizes what is really going on - I am tempted to play a game and see how many I can spot the next time I watch it. While this is not a bar to enjoying the movie (as I said I did enjoy the plot), I found it hard to like the main character because of it, and as an attorney I didn't appreciate the portrayal, particularly - and I find myself hoping there are very few attorneys like him.Furthermore, the story would have (in my opinion) been even more interesting if it had delved into how the legal system ACTUALLY handles such situations; it has happened in real life, and there are cases out there that the author could have utilized.  "Truth is stranger than fiction", and has the benefit of being truth.  While I don't think inaccuracy or "fluffing" of a character necessarily detracts from a movie or book, I think it did so here, at least for me.  The story could have been done equally well (probably better) without such a sleazy main character.
summary: Not a very accurate depiction of the justice system

reviewText: Matthew McConaughey proves he's not just a pretty face in The Lincoln Lawyer. It's difficult to translate books to the silver screen, and this is no exception. Based upon the novel by John Connelly, the movie lacks the heart that enlivened the written version. It does do justice, however, to the character of Mickey Haller, a smart, fast-talking defense attorney who knows all the tricks and doesn't hesitate to play them. Kind of a conman with a conscience, if you can picture that. I wondered about the choice of Mcconaughey to play Mick, but I'm happy to report that he captured the Haller essence. His client, a rich boy accused of assaulting a working girl, will pay very well indeed if exonerated, but Mick senses there's more to these accusations than meets the eye. A mature Marisa Tomei portrays Mickey's ex, and while she handles well the material she's given, the nature of their relationship (still loving each other) does not come through. William H. Macy shines as Haller's investigator, as does Laurence Mason, the chauffeur with a keen mind. Michael Pena, a now-incarcerated former client (you can't win 'em all) makes the most of the few key scenes in which he appears, forwarding the momentum of the plot.  But this is McConaughey's show, and if his performance here is anything to go by, his career should be taking off from here on out. As should director Brad Furman's.

reviewText: As you've no doubt worked out from the slew of 4 to 5 star reviews this film has received - Brad Furman's "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a superlative legal thriller very much in the vein of twisting John Grisham screen adaptations like "The Client" and "A Time To Kill".Adapted from Michael Connelly's book, the brilliant screenplay is written by John Romano - and it gets its hooks into you early and doesn't let go. It also helps that the entire cast is top notch - Francis Fisher plays the ruthlessly determined mum (of the accused), Bob Gunton (of The Shawshank Redemption) plays the defendant's family lawyer and employee of mum - a man who is all too willing to bend a few rules for his rich clients. Marisa Tomei plays Matt's long-suffering ex-wife and a prosecution lawyer in her own rite, William H. Macy plays Frank - Matt's equally long-suffering private detective partner and best friend. Josh Lucas plays the earnest but nave prosecuting lawyer, Laurence Mason plays Earl - Matt's savvy chauffeur (he drives The Lincoln) while both John Leguizamo and Michael Pena are exceptional as Latino hustlers and hoods.But the film belongs to the two principal leads - Ryan Phillippe brilliantly portraying the accused - a convincing weeper on the stand who may indeed be innocent - or may be a an artic-cold slasher monster who needs to be put down like a rabid dog and not just put away. Add to this a central performance from the all-too-often underrated Matthew McConaughey shining like a diamond throughout (a sleazy lawyer forced to face up to his questionable legal tactics and outcomes) - and the whole thing feels like a really well-made movie - because that's exactly what it is (dialogue above).The BLU RAY print is immaculate throughout and accentuates the gritty sweatiness of so many scenes.It's not all genius of course, but "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a hugely enjoyable watch - when such things seem to be in short supply these days.Put it high on your 'must watch' rental list...
summary: "...What If I Can't Recognize Innocence Anymore..."

reviewText: Have you ever watched a movie thinking before hand it would be a good movie only to discover that it was just so so once it finished? A movie that just leaves you feeling a bit bland, as if had you not watched it you wouldn't notice it but that you thought was entertaining enough anyway? Such is the case with THE LINCOLN LAWYER.Based on the best seller by Michael Connelly it tells the tale of slick lawyer Mick Haller (Matthew McConaughey), a stereotypical lawyer who will do most anything to get his client off be he guilty or not. Mick is also likely to take his client for as much as he can get while the getting is good. Not the most loveable character you'll find in a movie.Things get odd when Mick takes on a case for bail bondsmen/friend named Val Valenzuela (John Leguizamo). He has a client in need of an attorney, a young and wealthy guy named Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillipe) accused of attempting to rape and beat a young woman. Roulet claims innocence from the start and Mick is willing to take him at his word. Refusing money from his mother to differentiate the client from the witness base, Mick sets out to discover all he can about the case and all involved.Using his best friend and investigator Frank Levin (William H. Macy), he sets out building an alibi for his client. But when he has Frank look into something different, Frank ends up dead and the most likely suspect in Mick's eye is Roulet. The problem is being his attorney Roulet is protected by the lawyer/client privilege. And when ties to a case that didn't set well with Mick years ago start to form, he begins to wonder just who this young man really is.Along the way we meet an assortment of characters to round out the film. Marisa Tomei stars as Maggie McPherson, Mick's ex-wife who works in the D.A.'s office. There are several policemen who don't care for Mick's way of doing things, especially helping criminals evade justice headed by Bryan Cranston. And then there's Earl (Laurence Mason), Mick's chauffer, the man who drives the Lincoln town car that connects to the movie's title. Mick doesn't use an office you see, he spends most of his time in his car.The mystery involved doesn't offer an incredibly difficult plot to follow nor puzzle to solve. Who did what to whom becomes pretty evident early on. The best part of the film deals with Mick's trying to find a way to not break the law by turning in his client and at the same time finding a way to get him convicted of the crime.The performances here are for the most part pretty standard. There is no break out performance to be seen but everyone does a fine job. The cinematography is well done with a few hand held shots that aren't so obnoxious as to get in the way. The direction feels more by the book than anything. As I said, this movie offers a decent mystery but for the most part feels sort of bland. Still, when it comes to a rental its better than a number of movies out there and you just might enjoy it.

reviewText: Michael Connelly's THE LINCOLN LAWYER is given a fitting screen translation and much of the credit goes to Matthew McConaughey.  In his best performance in years, Matthew's spirited personification of ace defender Mickey is the foundation of a labrynthine plot full of twists and turns, shady low-life and unexpected heroes.  The familiar LA background pulsates in new ways, achieving an almost surreal quality.  The supporting cast is superb:  Marisa Tomei as Mickey's ex is sultry but maternal too; William H. Macy shines as Mickey's friend and PI; Ryan Phillippe as the smarmy Louis Roulet; Michael Pena as the wrongly convicted murderer; John Leguizamo as the treacherous bail bondsman; Frances Fisher as Roulet's cool mama; Shea Wigham, the snitch; Bryan Cranston and Michaela Conlin's detectives and Josh Lucas' self-important prosecutor.  One of this year's strongest ensemble casts.  LINCOLN LAWYER moves well, holding your interest right to the last scene.  Ooops...forgot country singer Trace Adkins marvelous bit as a heavy-duty biker.  Fans of courtroom mysteries should love this movie!

reviewText: Brad Furman's "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a slick, fast-moving, outstandingly entertaining legal thriller about a defense attorney burdened with the client from Hell. Mickey Haller (Matthew McConaughey)--known as "The Lincoln Lawyer" because his office is the back seat of his chauffeured Lincoln Town Car--is an arrogant hotshot who prides himself on being able to play the legal system like Jimi Hendrix played his guitar. After several plot twists and turns, however, Mickey suddenly finds the system playing him. He's even being framed to look like the perpetrator of capital crimes, and because of attorney-client privilege he faces disbarment--or worse--if he tells what he knows.To say anything more about the plot of "The Lincoln Lawyer" would be a capital crime in itself. Let's just say that the movie keeps you on the edge of your seat literally to the last minute, and that even the savviest thriller fan won't guess all the surprises Furman has in store. Matthew McConaughey hasn't been this good since he played another, very different lawyer in "A Time to Kill," and he is matched by an impeccable supporting cast including Marisa Tomei as his prosecutor ex-wife, Ryan Philippe as a rich kid accused of rape, Frances Fisher as Philippe's imperious mother, William H. Macy as a scruffy P.I. and John Leguizamo as a sleazy bail bondsman. Airtight and engrossing, "The Lincoln Lawyer" is pretty much flawless for what it is.

reviewText: It's been a while since there has been a decent courtroom drama, but happily now that one has come along, it turns out to be worth the wait.  Matthew MaConaughy is the titular purveyor of legal expertise, which he does not from an office of leather topped desks and imposing shelves full of legal tomes, but rather from the back seat of his Lincoln.  It soon becomes clear that he is quite happy to represent anyone at all, indeed that this may even come from his conscience - his greatest fear being that he might have the responsibility of defending someone who is actually innocent.  It's an interesting and satisfyingly explored twist on the usual moral-high-ground style lawyers we usually see in these movies.  However his next case defending the rich Ryan Phillippe character, turns out to be challenging both to his sense of what he knows is right, and a challenge to his skills in out-manipulating.All this leads to some satisfying courtroom scenes, and perhaps does not hold too many genuine surprises.  Except perhaps for the biggest surprise of the movie - a remarkable return to form for Maconaughy, after years in sub-par rom-coms, his first return to the courtroom sinceA Time to Kill [Blu-ray] makes you wish he'd never left. He certainly holds the movie together, far outshining the lesser role given to Ryan Phillips.  Which is not to say his is the only good performance, surrounded by an assortment of top notch character actors (Marisa Tomei, John Leguizamo, William Macy and others) adding a real sense of reality and grittiness to the movie.I liked it, and I recommend it.  It loses a star for a certain level of predictability and a less than charismatic performance from Ryan Phillippe, but still gets a solid 4 stars on the basis of terrific characterization and interesting spin on the courtroom drama formula.

reviewText: Agatha Christie would be proud of the five-twist ending to THE LINCOLN LAWYER. The film is clearly top-notch and street smart. It's the most efficient, solidly crafted courtroom thriller since PRIMAL FEAR and WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION. It has so many twists and turns that it's likely that the popular mystery writer would be giving it her approval.It also reignites the career of Matthew McConaughey as an actor, not just a charismatic star. He manages to be smoothly appealing despite playing a corrupt lawyer who has no scruples in defending guilty clients as long as they provide the cash flow he demands. It's only after defending RYAN PHILLIPPE from a charge of murder and rape that he realizes he does have a few scruples left. And the plot twists provided by the screenwriter John Romano from the novel by Michael Connelly, are deftly handled for maximum shock effect. Brad Furman keeps the direction tight and forceful.The cast surrounding McConaughey has been selected with care and all of them offer realistic performances. Marisa Tomei is appealing as his ex-wife who knows his shortcomings but is still attracted to him, and William H. Macy delivers a solid performance as his investigator friend. Ryan Phillippe is excellent as the client whose surface appearance belies the fact that he's as street smart as his sleazy lawyer, and FRANCES FISHER is outstanding in a small but pivotal role as the young man's protective mother.Not since the days of PRIMAL FEAR and WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION has there been a more intelligent script than this one, designed to baffle and blindside the viewer in the course of unraveling some startling surprises.By all means, highly recommended for fans of this genre.

reviewText: In a nutshell, "The Lincoln Lawyer" story is: A slick lawyer skilled at getting small time perps out of trouble lands a high paying gig and, possibly for the first time, a potentially innocent client; things get interesting when he must figure out which of his clients is guilty, and who - the guy already serving time, or the guy who is likely to serve time - really is the criminal, and how to keep or get the other one out of prison.It's the sort of story with a lot of potential, and this film doesn't let down. Matthew McConaughey (the slick lawyer) is at ease in the role, and transitions from easy-going and slick to worried and revengeful when the time is right. The rest of the cast is likewise excellent in their roles. The story is clever and intriguing, and progresses at an ideal pace - not too fast to lose you, but not so slow that you're bored.5/5 stars, for a fun, interesting legal thriller

reviewText: I saw this again last night and it holds up beautifully.  Connelly should be very pleased and ready to sign on for a series of Mickey Haller films.  This is smooth, effective filmmaking: a strong plot, exceptional actors, top production values and just enough sex and violence to earn the R without distracting us unnecessarily.Matthew McConaughey plays Mickey Haller to a fare-thee-well.  He is defending a decadent sleazeball and, in return, pocketing a tidy fee.  At the same time his heart is breaking over the fact that he struck a plea deal for a former client who, he now knows, was innocent.  The man is rotting in San Quentin and will likely spend 15 years of his life there.  Suddenly it hits him: the sleazeball he is currently defending may well have perpetrated the murder for which his other, falsely-accused client, took the fall.  This guy likes to kill women and then watch others serve time for it.  He also likes to entrap his lawyer, who is bound by attorney-client privilege rules.  Mick has to get the sleazeball off but, simultaneously, he has to also see him convicted and his prior client freed.How will he do that?  That’s the nub of the mystery.  In the process he will be supported by his ex-wife Maggie (Marisa Tomei), his investigator (William H. Macey) and the head of a biker gang (Trace Adkins).  This is delicious L.A. crime narrative.  If you haven’t seen it yet, a significant treat awaits you.

I thought it was fascinating to watch an incredibly arrogant defense lawyer deal with the uglier side of the legal system -- finding out that one of his many clients that he assumed was guilty is innocent and one of the clients he thinks is innocent could possibly be guilty. Everybody has a right to a fair trial, but that lawyer-client privilege can become a love/hate relationship when the lawyer wants to shake the client loose and can't. This was a great movie. reviewText: *A Brief Note to Readers: If you find this review "not helpful", please take a moment to tell me why in the comment section. Thank you.*A crime thriller adapted from Michael Connelly's best selling novel of the same name, "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a solid and entertaining film that is easy to follow.  It is rife with noteworthy performances and events that offer its main character a new outlook on himself and the law.Mick Haller (McConnaughey) is a high-profile defense attorney in LA who is known for his good looks, devil-may-care persona and fetish for Lincoln towncars.  His ex-wife and fellow attorney Maggie (Tomei) is immune to the facade, decrying his sensibilities as a lawyer ("I'm trying like hell to keep scumbags off the street while you're busy putting them right back on it") right along with local law enforcement ("Where does someone like you sleep at night?  With all the scum you represent?").  Haller laughs it off but his good humor is stifled when he offers to defend Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe) against a rape charge. When his client's self-proclaimed innocence doesn't mesh with the facts and things get sinister and dangerous, Haller ends up fighting for his life to render a verdict he doesn't believe in.Though this movie was enjoyable, it takes one too many liberties for my liking.  First, when Roulet is on the stand, he directly addresses the jury to once again proclaim his innocence while giving them a sob story (this would never fly in a real courtroom).  Then, towards the film's end, Mick calls in a "favor" and exacts some justice of his own.  I just can't see him getting away with this one considering the circumstances: he represents the people who perform said "favor", his victim is able to place him at a specific location at a specific time, and there is property damage and assault involved.  Far-fetched, in my opinion, but I guess at this point the audience is only supposed to care about seeing a scumbag get what he deserves.  And let's not even mention the unlicensed firearm he uses to defend himself during a skirmish.What viewers can fathom is Mick's dilemma in defending a man whose innocence is either questionable or false, and McConnaughey renders his character's tribulation splendidly.  Though I don't think it equals his performance in "A Time To Kill", it comes fairly close.  Phillippe is passable as the arrogant Roulet.  He doesn't come off as menacing as the character could be - all I saw was a Machiavellian pipsqueak but perhaps this is the interpretation the director wanted. It's a shame that Tomei is relegated to the background; I wanted to see more of her, especially since her character was an attorney.  Most everyone else ranges from good to serviceable.  The only error in casting I see here is William H. Macy - why give a man that talented such a short-lived role?  What a waste.Though this kind of story has been done before in different ways and possesses a predictable outcome (most movies like this don't let the bad guys get away), "The Lincoln Lawyer" is decent entertainment for someone who wants an exciting plot and a denouement that gives a sense of closure.

reviewText: This movie perfectly meets the requirements of the genre, and the only reason I give it four stars instead of five is that the genre itself -- slick, plot-driven, "sting" movie -- is a pretty easy thing to do and doesn't really stretch the actors all that much.  I enjoyed the novel on which this movie was based, and now, about 4 years later, I've gotten round to the movie.  It does justice to the tone, spirit and much of the detail of the movie.  The cast is absolutely up to the job -- McConaughy, Marisa Tomei, William H. Macy, Ryan Philippe, and, in a small role, Bryan Cranston -- all are fine, as are the less well-known supporters.  If I had to pick one out, I would say that Macy brings something -- maybe just his look -- that you remember in a quite small role that is nonetheless important to the plot.  Pacing, camera work, music -- all apt.  So if you like plots that have more twists than a corkscrew and haven't seen this one, it won't disappoint you.

reviewText: Ryan Philippe has a habit of playing opposite more charismatic male stars,here against Mathew McConaughey,in Breach it was as understudy to a mole(Chris Cooper) in the FBI.In both films he ostensibly tries to outsmart andmanipulate more experienced men.For Mick Haller (McConaughey),a Los Angeles criminal defence lawyer,who operates out of the back of his Lincoln Towncar,having spent his life defending petty gutter-variety criminals,unexpectedly lands the chance of a lifetime,defending a rich kid realtor,who is accused of attempted rape and murder.Part of the conflict in this film is that Mick, being bound by attorney-client confidentiality rules, can't go to the police or the DA. Roulet(Philippe) broke into his house, threatened his family, stole his gun (of course, that isn't proven, but circumstantial is strong), and his friend/investigator is murdered and he is being framed for it... and still, Mick has no options other than to keep quiet? The whole point of the film is the way Haller dealt with the problem. He outplayed Roulet. It wasn't very realistic but it was entertaining! You also have the fact that his current case was connected to another one of his client's cases.Not sure how that would complicate things but he also has a responsibility to that client.His current client actually confessed to a murder involving that client:the sight of Michael Peña, as one of Mick's old clients,going from freaked-out innocent to stone-cold lifer in a few short scenes.Ms. Tomei plays a character and not just the love interest. She isn't the star, of course, but without her and the other exceptionally well-cast supporting players, Mr. McConaughey would have a tougher time making you believe that he was to the sleaze born. After his breakthrough in A Time To Kill, either he or his management team fell into the familiar Hollywood trap of following the money rather than following the talent. Here, he infuses life into a wonderfully seedy character, a lived in quality. Mick's confidence about his place in the social food chain is upended by a building sense of doubt and guilt, culminating in telling moment when he says, "There's no client as scary as an innocent man.". Mick's descent into self-questioning limbo ends up tainting the lives of his straggly haired investigator (William H. Macy) and his district attorney ex-wife (Marisa Tomei), the few fledgling branches making up his hollow family tree. and Furman can't help but drench the film in unnecessary lens flares, split screens, and jump cuts. All the twists and turns add up to little more than an anti-climactic showdown and a simplistic moral awakening,with the cheasy ending of sucking it to a repeat client next time.

reviewText: Based on a Michael Connelly bestselling novel, "The Lincoln Lawyer" follows the story of Mickey Haller (Matthew McConaughey), the "Lincoln Lawyer" of the title, who defends a wealthy family's son Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe), accused of beating up a prostitute Reggie Campo (Margarita Levieva). As the story unfolds, however, Mickey realizes - maybe too late - that the case is not what it at first appears to be.Admittedly, the central mystery of the legal thriller is not as engaging as the character McConaughey plays, a criminal defense lawyer whose "office" is the backseat of a Lincoln continental. Clever and witty, Mickey is a capable lawyer, always knows what he is doing, and though he is not infallible (just like any of us), he knows what he should do, having his own code of ethics.The script is overlong (sometimes it feels like watching a pilot episode for a TV series), but is populated with interesting characters played by the talented cast including Frances Fisher, Bob Gunton, John Leguizamo, William H. Macy, Michael Peña and Marisa Tomei. Josh Lucas also appears as a state prosecutor, who gives a nice contrast to McConaughey's character.The courtroom drama in the film's second half will keep you interested with some surprises, though you know that this hardly happens in real life. Directed by Brad Furman (his second feature), the well-paced film is also notable for the effective use of on-location shots of Los Angeles. "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a solid and entertaining legal thriller with memorable characters.
summary: (3.5 STARS) Solid and Entertaining Legal Thriller
